conclusion: I'll analyze the velocity-time graph to determine if objects A and B have the same acceleration at time $t_1$.
The graph shows velocity ($v$) versus time ($t$) for two objects A and B. Both objects start at the same location and move in the same direction.
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity. Mathematically, acceleration $a = \frac{dv}{dt}$, which is the slope of the velocity-time graph at any point.
For Object A: At time $t_1$, the velocity curve for A is a straight line with a positive slope.

premise: For Object A: At time $t_1$, the velocity curve for A is a straight line with a positive slope.
conclusion: Object A has a constant positive acceleration at time $t_1$.
For Object B: At time $t_1$, the velocity curve for B appears to be a decreasing curve (looks like exponential decay), with a negative slope.

premise: For Object B: At time $t_1$, the velocity curve for B appears to be a decreasing curve (looks like exponential decay), with a negative slope.
conclusion: Object B has a negative acceleration at time $t_1$.

premise: Object A has a positive acceleration at time $t_1$. Object B has a negative acceleration at time $t_1$.
conclusion: Since the slopes are different (one positive, one negative), the accelerations are different.

conclusion: No, the two objects do not have the same acceleration at time $t_1$. Object A has a positive acceleration while Object B has a negative acceleration at that time.
